title: Cleanaway clobbered on soft first half
text:
An economic slowdown, softer commodity prices and fewer trucks shipping their waste into Queensland from New South Wales have combined to undermine profit growth for waste management group Cleanaway.

Shares in the company tumbled as much as 24 per cent in early trading on Friday after chief executive Vik Bansal warned that first-half profits were under pressure and weren't likely to show any growth compared with the same period a year ago.

But he said over the full-year, Cleanaway was still expected to deliver some profit growth as price increases and a cost-cutting program found their way to the bottomline.

Cleanaway has been hit by a softer economy and a drop-off in trucks filled with waste coming into Queensland from NSW.

The share price recovered partially later on Friday.

Mr Bansal also told shareholders at the group's annual meeting that he was ''quite confident'' the $66 million acquisition of the recycling operations of the failed SKM business in Victoria would ultimately deliver value to shareholders. The acquisition is set to be finalised at the end of October.
description: Cleanaway chief executive Vik Bansal says Australia is ''sorting'' its waste but doesn't actually recycle.
